messageBody:
Paul:

I agree that it is important to keep Eat easy to read in small font sizes.  Following the QM too closely would make that more difficult.  That was one of the problems I saw with Jerome.

Paige

paulhtremblay wrote:

--- In Read_Alphabet@ yahoogroups. com, Gregory Weidman <delrayva@.. .>
wrote:

Thaks for the feedback!

>
> To my eyes there are three problems with Thoth, although I'm sure
there are many who would disagree with me.
>
> 1. Yo-yo looks too much like a capital P from T.O. The top should
be more rounded.

That is easy to fix.

> 2. Eat slopes too far to the right.

I made it this way on purpose so it could be read easily at small
sizes and so it could be distinguished from Ooze. Now I can easily fix
it, but should I? It is tricky making fonts because you want to them
the ideal way, but often they are less readable when you make them as
the ideal.

> 3. Ha-ha should have a bit more curve to it -- more of a hook than a
right angle. However, I know that in my handwriting I rather deviate
from the QM in this regard. My ha-ha looks almost exactly like a
mirror image of pipe -- QM doesn't do this.

I could easily change this, too.

>
> I note that Kick looks in Thoth-font much the way I write it.
However, I think that the riser in Kick in the QM curves a little to
the left. I like the way it looks in Thoth-font, but it may not
please someone who is more of a purist.

Good, I'm with you on this one! Originally I made it as it appeared in
the QM manual, but it looked terrible on paper because it allowed too
much space between it and the next character. Making Kick more
vertical really improved the overall appearances.

Note: I don't know if we should slavisly follow what Read did in his
manual. After all, fonts in TO don't follow one design. The first
printers actually did try to imitate the writing of the scribes before
they realized they had to part from that tradition. Likewise, a font
may have to differ somewhat from QS writing. I hope this doesn't come
off as defensive. I really do want others' feedback, but I do want the
font to be readable at fairly small sizes. On the other hand, I don't
want the letters to look so different from what is expected that users
will stumble upon reading it. (Also, I have heard that Read didn't
take great care in composing the alphabet in the QM. Too bad he didn't
make a font like he did for Shavian so we would have someting better
to go by!)

I'm surprised you see problems with those three letters because I
thought others would be more problematic.

Thanks again

Paul
